history.content:
We just sent this to everyone enrolled or waitlisted in CS161, but in case you didn't receive it, here's our introductory letter for the fall semester:

Last semester was a triage semester: we got hit midway through with a crisis that forced us to move online and our goal was to salvage as much as possible. This semester is a little different.  The unique response of the US to the Coronavirus pandemic[1] has ensured that Berkeley can not safely open for large-scale in-person operations[2]. So the theme for this semester is "Embrace the Suck". We understand this is a difficult time for everyone, and we are going to do the best we can to learn as much as possible and keep all of us safe, healthy, and happy.

To help us plan the course around your schedule, please fill out this survey as soon as possible: [link redacted, email peyrin@berkeley.edu if you plan on taking the course and need the link]

The rest of this email is an overview of our plans for this semester. Detailed logistics are also available at https://cs161.org/policies.

Live lectures and discussions will be held at scheduled times over Zoom. We’ll use the results of the survey to determine lecture and discussion time. Attendance is optional but encouraged: minor extra credit is available for participation. Lecture recordings and discussion worksheet walkthroughs will also be posted for those who can’t attend live.

We will have one midterm (Friday, October 9, time TBA pending survey results) and a final (Thursday, December 17, 11:30am-2:30pm PT). An alternate exam time will be available for students with time conflicts or students in inconvenient time zones.

We will also use several tools to encourage exam integrity.  If we told our students “exams will be unproctored and we will not do any detection for academic dishonesty” we would be disappointed if less than 100% of our students cheated. But since we don’t want that we will use several techniques to detect cheating.

We plan to proctor exams over Zoom. See https://cs161.org/exam for detailed proctoring logistics. Additionally, we may ask some students to take a short verbal exam as part of our "trust-but-verify" policy. Finally, we have other technical cheating detection measures that we won’t disclose.

We understand that this is a stressful time for everyone. If you have any extenuating circumstances or you’re feeling stressed, please don’t hesitate to reach out. We will have a form for requesting extensions, or you can post on Piazza or email course staff directly. Course staff is here to support you.

Feel free to reach out if you have any other questions or concerns. In the end, we hope to make this as good a semester as possible.

-Nick, Peyrin, and the rest of the 161 staff

[1] OK, you can argue that the UK has decided to do US-lite, but apart from that the US experience is uniquely incompetent.

[2] The problem is any in-person activity (except perhaps outdoor-only meetings with masks standing far apart) is not safe until the case rate is vastly lower. It is even harder within the university context as we would be importing the COVID policies of the worst of the state and nation. The actual risk of getting seriously ill or dying for Berkeley students is low, but students act as reserve of infection for others and the risk is non-negligible even for the student population.
